[h1]Review After 100% Completion[/h1]

[h2]Recommendation: Recommended[/h2]

[h3]What I Liked (Pros):[/h3]
+ Movement and gunplay are phenomenal, grapple hooking, gliding, sliding, and chaining it all together feels buttery smooth. It’s easily the best-feeling Borderlands game to date. Even spawning your vehicle and riding through the open world feels awesome, fast, responsive, and reminiscent of Destiny’s Sparrow in the best way.
+ Open world and sandbox design are a huge win. The verticality, traversal options, and sheer scale make exploration genuinely fun.
+ Skyboxes are jaw-dropping, especially in the second half of the game. The celestial vistas in zones like Dominion and Terminus Range are unforgettable, [spoiler] especially the moment you ride the sky lift into orbit, and the haunting beauty of the area where you find Lilith. [/spoiler] Those visuals were next-level.
+ Gun customization is wild. Mixing and matching manufacturer parts creates an insane amount of weapon variants to chase, it’s loot heaven.
+ Customization is excellent. Tons of skins and colour options for your character, guns, vehicle, and Echo (your little personal robot). Unlocking them through challenges and mission completions feels earned and rewarding.
+ Side quests are surprisingly excellent. There’s a ton of them, and most feel meaningful. Some even outshine the main missions. Standouts include:
Escape Room – A puzzle-heavy mission that rewards observation and lateral thinking.
Meat Is Murder – A twisted culinary mystery in The Fadefields.
Vend of the Line – A noir-style investigation in Carcadia Burn.
Abduction Injunction – Alien conspiracy meets bureaucratic chaos.
No Place Like Home – Emotional and eerie, set in a shifting dreamscape.
Claptrap’s Contractual Crisis – Classic humour and surprisingly heartfelt moments.
+ Story is solid. It’s second only to Borderlands 2, and let’s be honest, nothing’s ever going to top Handsome Jack.
+ Villains like Calous and Vile Lictor are far more memorable than the main antagonist, Timekeeper. They steal the show.
+ Faction design is a big step up. The Outbounders and Electi are way more interesting than anything we got in Borderlands 3.
+ Boss mechanics are genuinely impressive. Some fights rival Destiny 2 in complexity, it’s not just “stand on a plate.” You’ve got multi-phase encounters, environmental hazards, and puzzle-like mechanics that keep you on your toes. It’s a huge step forward for the series.
+ No in-game shop. No microtransactions, no premium cosmetics, everything is earned through gameplay. It’s refreshing and makes progression feel meaningful.

[h3]What I Didn’t Like (Cons):[/h3]
- Performance issues crop up way too often, especially in high-density combat zones and open-world traversal. For how the game looks, which, yes, is a visual step up from Borderlands 3, it still shouldn’t be running at 40–60 FPS. It’s a cel-shaded game, and the frame drops are brutal. Spawning your vehicle and riding through the open world causes massive dips, especially after long rides.
- Endgame content is thin. Once the story wraps, there’s not much to keep you grinding beyond loot.
- Timekeeper is forgettable. As the main villain, they’re overshadowed by stronger side antagonists.
- UI and inventory management still feels clunky, especially when sorting through hundreds of weapon variants.
- Multi-character progression is a mess. You can boost a new character to level 30, sure, but everything else? You’re stuck redoing the same grind. Map fog doesn’t carry over, so you have to re-explore every zone. Gun manufacturer challenges and faction reputation, none of it is account-wide. It’s exhausting. If you want to experiment with builds, the game punishes you for it.

[h3]Wishlist – Things I’d Love to See Added:[/h3]
[list]
[*] Endgame Raids or Dungeons – High-level co-op challenges with unique loot and mechanics would give players a reason to stick around. 
[*] Performance Optimization – The game should run better without relying on AI upscaling tools like DLSS or whatever Randy suggested — especially since those features are only available on 4000-series GPUs and above. A cel-shaded Borderlands game shouldn’t need cutting-edge hardware to maintain stable frames. 
[*] Expanded Faction Systems – Reputation, perks, and faction-specific gear could deepen engagement. 
[*] More Traversal Challenges – Parkour puzzles or time trials using the movement system would be a great addition. 
[*] Account-Wide Progression – Map fog, challenges, and reputation should carry across characters. Let us grind once, not five times.
[/list]

[h3]Achievements:[/h3]
Most achievements are pretty manageable and can be earned just by playing through the game and exploring thoroughly. There’s a bit of grind if you’re going for 100%, but nothing outrageous, except for one: getting all Vault Hunters to level 50 and unlocking their vehicles. That one takes serious time.

There are also two missable achievements to watch out for:
[list]
[*] All Things Vend – Can be missed if you don’t follow the correct steps during the “Vend of the Line” side mission.
[*] Rift Incompatible – Requires interacting with Oddman’s frozen body at the end of “Exit Through the Rift Shop.” You only get one shot at it — no replay.
[/list]
And yes, difficulty-based achievements exist. Reaching Ultimate Vault Hunter Rank 5 (UVH5) is one of them. It’s tied to post-game progression and requires pushing through increasingly tough enemies and bosses. It’s not brutal, but it’s definitely a challenge. The grindy ones are listed below.
[list]
[*] Catch-A-Ride - Collect all personal vehicles, to get these you will need to reach level 50 on all vault hunters.
[*] Area of Expertise - Complete any Gear Challenge category.
[*] Grassroots Campaigner - Complete all side missions.
[*] Brand Equity - Complete any Manufacturer Challenge category.
[/list]
The rest of the list is pretty chill, you’ll knock out most of them naturally as you complete zones, finish missions, and collect along the way.

[h3]Memorable Quotes:[/h3]
[list]
[*]“Well if it isn’t my favorite…… it’s you”
[*]What? Oh, yeah! Followed the safety manual for flinging people over the void to the letter, I did!
[*]"wait, why am I buying your shite"
[*]"Tips welcome - money, not advice."
[*]"You'll never get me plucky arms!"
[*]"You keep talkin' to me - you know I'm a HOLOGRAM, right?"
[*]"Oh, what a mighty Vault Hunter! ...and you're here too."
[*]"One man's junk is another man's... junk. But hey - CREDITS!"
[/list]

[h3]Final Thoughts:[/h3]
Borderlands 4 is the most mechanically refined game in the series. The movement system alone, with its grapple, glide, and slide, makes traversal and combat just feels really fun. It’s the first time I’ve felt truly free in a Borderlands game, and the open world complements that beautifully.

The story doesn’t quite reach the heights of Borderlands 2, but it’s close. Timekeeper is a weak link, but Calous and Vile Lictor more than make up for it. The factions are richer, the world more alive, and the side quests are genuinely some of the best content in the game.

Performance issues and a lacklustre endgame hold it back from perfection, but the core experience is so strong it’s easy to forgive. That said, the multi-character grind is a real buzzkill. If they want players to experiment with builds and alts, they’ve got to make that process smoother. Right now, it feels like punishment for wanting to try something new.

Still, Borderlands 4 proves the franchise has evolved in all the right ways. If they build on this foundation, the next entry could be legendary.

Hands down, the best Borderlands since BL2 and the best shooter this year.

I was super skeptical before release, cringed hard at their marketing campaign, and had zero plans to touch this game. But an empty November for new releases pushed me to buy it, and I haven't regretted it for a second.

The main thing is the upgraded movement and gunplay - it's just freaking fantastic. Zipping around arenas is lightning-fast and lets you pull off wild tricks with double jumps, dashes, and slides mid-fight. I absolutely adore combat systems like this (similar to what you find in Echo Point Nova and Doom Eternal).

The new gun randomization system so cool. It's not just random guns from one manufacturer anymore; there's a deep parts system where a component from one manufacturer, like a reloading system, can end up on a gun from another manufacturer. This is fire! You can get completely insane combinations, and it's awesome.

The loot drop system is still too random and doesn't take your character or class into account, dumping tons of useless gear on you. You can definitely run into the classic problem humanity created back in the Diablo 2 days, where enemies get noticeably stronger as you level up, but you don't get any decent gear. I struggled a bit around level 42+ until I stopped and intentionally farmed a boss for the gear I needed.

The open world itself feels like a mix of Diablo 4 and Far Cry. Yeah, it's an open world with points of interest, and the map is completely packed with content, but there are also world events - a boss can spawn, or a global event with better rewards can kick off.

There is an extreme amount of content in this game. Most of the side quests, and there's a shit-ton of them, are written well. Yeah, most of them are comedic and reference old memes. The main story campaign tries for serious drama but flies right past your ears because of how cliche it is.

Overall, my impressions are only positive. The game is low-stress and doesn't demand heavy time investment. You can easily drop it for a week and then just as easily pick it back up and continue.

As for optimization, not sure what the problem was, it was probably worse at launch, but on mid-tier hardware, I have no issues. Over 100 FPS on high settings, and the game looks damn good. I don't know if it uses hardware RT, but the lighting in the game looks absolutely magnificent.

Cons:
1) No option to set Claptrap's volume to 200%.
2) Upcoming DLC with new regions, THE MAP IS ALREADY BLOODY HUGE

Borderlands 4 delivers exactly what fans expect: chaotic gunfights, over-the-top humor, and an endless hunt for better loot. While the story follows the familiar Borderlands formula, the game shines through its fast-paced combat and impressive variety of weapons. The updated skill trees and improved enemy AI make encounters more dynamic, especially during boss fights.

Although the game is fully playable solo, Borderlands 4 clearly performs at its best with friends. Cooperative play not only makes tougher encounters more manageable but also enhances the overall fun combining abilities, sharing loot strategies, and coordinating attacks truly elevates the experience. The multiplayer scaling system is smoother than ever, rewarding teamwork with better drops and more efficient progression.

Despite a few pacing issues and occasional technical hiccups, Borderlands 4 remains a highly enjoyable looter-shooter. It’s not a complete reinvention, but it’s a confident step forward for the series best enjoyed with a squad by your side.

I already know I will miss this game when I'm eventually done with it.

I play as Rafa and I love his witty commentary, while the background characters manage to make you feel for them. Don't except storytelling mastery of sorts, but it is solid after the cringe-fest that was Borderlands 3.

I can't ignore the fact that the optimization is lacking big time here, but playing on a high-end system I encountered zero issues. And I need to use DLSS in order to get over 60FPS at 4K with a GeForce RTX 5080, so make of that what you will. I'll start by saying I've been a fan of the mainline series since the original Borderlands, which was probably my first First Person Shooter on PC. I've played all the FPSs in this franchise (except Wonderlands, which actually ran worse for me than this game does). Given this perspective, people familiar with the series will probably get the most out of this review.

From what I've seen around, the majority of the criticism for this game is story and performance related. Both of these complaints are pretty well founded, but in my opinion the story in this game is the best post-Borderlands 2. Granted, that it isn't saying a lot. But to give credit where its due, I found the humor actually enjoyable rather than cringeworthy, and the side quests were thoughtful instead just being a cheap laugh. We get actual character growth in some of the NPCs. The writing quality is there in this game, but it suffered under some poor pacing decisions that likely are a result of The Open World design. There are plenty of reviews on the storytelling, so I'm going to focus on other things.

The class design has gotten better with each game. The potential build diversity is definitely the greatest its ever been, and I'm happy to see that there are plenty of skills that additionally benefit your team. I'm all for incentivizing teamwork in a co-op game. Not a lot to say here, just that if you've liked the design direction of the classes as they've evolved over across the series, this is building further upon that.

For the guns, we've got the same high quality we've come to expect from the franchise, with a few improvements. We're getting mashups of manufacturer gimmicks on weapons now, called Licensed Parts, which is great. Atlas homing bullets and Jakobs ricochet on crit on the same gun? Amazing. We've gotten a bunch of new underbarrel attachments now too, including laser beams, homing rockets, flame throwers and more. In Borderlands 3, I don't think I found a single one that was worth using, but most of the ones I've tried in this game have been something I look forward to using once they are off cooldown. As a side note, the new Ripper manufacturer is designed to look like kitbashed guns, like they took several guns from different manufacturers and slapped them together, sort of like how the new Liscensed part system works.

I think a lot of the issues with the story can actually be traced back to one core game design choice: The Open World. This has not been the franchises strong suit, with the open maps tending to be a bunch of nothing you drive your car through as quickly as possible, and the vehicle combat has never been good, so this was a big concern of mine going into the game. What we got, I have mixed feelings on. The story was obviously chopped up to fit The Open World design, which sucks. But we did get double jumps, a glide pack, instant summon vehicles almost anywhere, and a (albeit not well implemented) grapple grabber. These can mostly be combined for some pretty fun movement options, like jumping off your vehicle as its jumping to reach great heights, or doing so while boosting to glide great distances. The world is littered with little things to find, from secret chests to a measly Marcus Bobblehead, and all these new movement options make it fun to explore, rather than tedious. Thankfully, and ironically, the game with The Open World has no forced vehicle combat segments. My biggest let-down is the grapple grabber. It can only be used as a grapple at specifically designated spots, and they come in two varieties: the Spiderman Swing, and the ledge jump. The Spiderman Swing type lets you carry your momentum into your air jumps and a bit of your glide pack, making for some really fun and fast travel around the areas that have them. They're unfortunately rather rare. The second type is the most common, and they yoink you up to a ledge and drop you on the platform above them. Some of them allow you to carry momentum beyond the landing point, but most of them abruptly stop you mid air over the landing spot. These are as common as they are disappointing. The grabber part of the grapple grabber lets you pick up throwable explosives around the map (and is sometimes used for quest MacGuffins, too). For some reason, the grabber uses the same keybind as your melee attack, so if you're approaching an explosive and decide to pick it up, you might find yourself suddenly punching the damn thing and blowing yourself up. Or you might go to punch a baddy in the face and find yourself holding an explosive instead. My last complaint is that the world collision geometry was not always designed with all the freedom of movement the player has access to in mind. You'll find ledges you should clearly be able to stand on, but you just can't, and slide in the air or even right through the surface instead. Also you can use your bike and glide pack together to climb most walls that aren't completely vertical, which is silly.

All in all, I'd say this is a game with great gameplay that took some risks trying new things, some of which didn't pay off this time around. In my opinion, the good outweighs the bad, because at the end of the day the game is still fun to me.

This is a difficult game to review and recommend because it is such a mixed bag. The gameplay is WONDERFUL in the improvements they made to the loot and farming loop. Being able to keep farming the same boss without having to save and exit to the menu then rejoin your friends in co-op is really nice, and they fixed the over abundance of legendaries that plagued Borderlands 3. Now farming and getting that perfect drop from a boss is extremely satisfying and i wouldn't be surprised if i spent 10 hours in farming alone on my first (and only for now) playthrough. Being able to dash, glide, and double jump also makes the farming feel fast and efficient, not to mention its just a very fun way to play the game and feels wonderful.
 
However, Borderlands 3's backlash for an awful story has made Gearbox resort to very safe, bland writing. The writing is overall an improvement, with some funny moments, and less cringe overall. There are no blatantly offensively annoying characters like BL3 but instead all of the characters are just slightly annoying at best. The game tries to set up some emotional moments but is too scared to set up any significant events to care about, and doesnt set you up to care about any of the characters in the game so nothing feels impactful. 

The Timekeeper unfortunately does not live up to the likes of Handsome Jack. I wouldn't have wanted them to try to imitate Jack but i think why Handsome Jack works so well in BL2 is because he is a constant threat to you and is constantly mocking, and getting in your way, and hurting the people you are close to. The Timekeeper is not this way, you rarely hear from him within the main 3 sections of the game, and have no reason to worry about him while you're going through 85% of the game. And none of the other 3 leaders are particularly intimidating or have a significant presence. I think if you heard from the leaders and the time keeper move often while doing the main missions it would make a big difference. Or if you heard from the timekeeper when you did a propaganda speaker or take over a bunker would do a lot to making him more present in the story, but I just didn't ever really think about him during most of the game. 

Another issue with the game is the lack of enemy variety, youll be fighting the same order soldiers and rippers for most of the game with some wildlife here and there. Maybe it would be enough enemies if it was a shorter game but the game took me 80 hours to beat and it got pretty tiring fighting the same enemies the whole time. I hope the DLCs don't have the Order in it and mixes up the game significantly so youre not just looking at Order architecture and enemies the whole time. 

If you're looking to play the game, I wouldn't recommend clearing out every objective and side activity. I think the bunkers and mines are fun with a small mini-boss within, but most of the other side content doesnt provide anything significant, and SDU tokens aren't extremely helpful since ammo drops are weighted to how much ammo you have in your guns. If you just run through the story and doing some side content here and there as you come across it i think youll have a good time. I am looking forward to replaying to interact with the other vault hunters i havent played as, Vex was a very fun and satisfying vault hunter, but i am not looking forward to fighting the same Order enemies and driving through the fairly bland environments over and over.

As for the end game, it seems fairly lackluster for now but they are planning more content. I am not a borderlands player that really interacts with the end game content very much but the lack of takedowns and raid bosses for now at launch is pretty unfortunate. 

I am excited to revisit the game sometime in 2026 to see how the DLC and new bosses and pearlescents feel but until then I don't want to play the game anymore, i'm burnt out and tired.

Here’s my review focusing only on the game itself — I’m leaving the PR drama and CEO controversies aside.

This was my first Borderlands game, and I was drawn in by the idea of an FPS with RPG mechanics. The movement looked fluid and snappy, almost reminiscent of DOOM (2016).
So, was the game fun? Yes — fun enough to keep me engaged despite the crashes and performance issues. And for me, that’s the core purpose of a game: to be enjoyable. On that front, it succeeds just enough to earn a positive review.

Do I regret my purchase? Also yes.
The overall experience didn’t feel worth the price, and I never felt motivated to convince friends to join me. When a game is this expensive, I expect something more than just basic entertainment — I expect an experience. Unfortunately, the story and characters have the depth of a puddle, the soundtrack is so forgettable I’m not sure the audio was even on, and the jokes land with all the grace of a bad medical diagnosis.

Visually, the environments are quite nice — though not the character models — but good visuals alone aren’t enough.

Final thoughts:
Maybe give it a try during a deep sale. As for me, that’s what I’ll do next time.

STORY – 7 Vaults out of 10
It feels like a big link, tying the last game to a potential future game, a spin-off.
It’s a standalone story about different people with different problems. The few cameos from characters of earlier games unfortunately don’t create the feeling that you’re playing Borderlands — more like something from this universe, but not quite the main thing.

GAMEPLAY – 8 XP points out of 10
Movement is MUCH more convenient now — you get a grappling hook for pulling yourself up, instant transportation, a jetpack — you can climb basically anywhere.
As for the skill tree (for me personally), there’s no point in mixing the branches; you can just invest in one of the three and you won’t lose (or gain) much. Shooting hasn’t really changed, except that the grenade slot now holds various rocket launchers (and machine guns) which used to be a separate weapon type.

CHARACTERS – 5 fingers out of 10
Back to the character topic — most of the negative points come from the story bosses. They’re forgettable and bland (except for one — and it’s not the main villain).
Friendly NPCs... well, they’re there. They exist to tick a box, but they don’t evoke any emotional response. Returning heroes from previous games are VERY few — you can count them on one hand. This isn’t BL3, where they even managed to bring up Rhys and Salvador. But hey, Moxxi is here — and that’s something.

GUNS / SHOOTING – 6 bullets out of 10
Apparently, after BL3 with its gazillion guns, the devs slowed down and... tightened the supply of good ammo (purple and orange; pearlescents won’t arrive until spring 2026). Don’t expect guaranteed legendaries from killing bosses — if you get a couple of purples, consider yourself lucky.
Whoever came up with the Order weapons this time — there’s a special slow-boiling cauldron waiting for you in hell.

GRAPHICS – 9 rainbow colors out of 10
A very beautifully crafted world. I liked the biomes — distinct parts of the map — as well as the overall color palette. It genuinely feels like a living world, not a washed-out something (like in BL1 and BL2). If BL3’s visuals satisfied you, this one won’t disappoint.

OPTIMIZATION – 4 shader compilations out of 10
HOW. TIRED. I AM. OF. COMPILING. SHADERS. EVERY. SINGLE. TIME.

Final score: 6.5 Borderlands out of 10

I do genuinely love this game. It's still really fun to play as Borderlands games always have been, and the gameplay is just as great as 3's. However, in the game's current state, I just cannot recommend it.

To put it simple, this is not a finished product. The unfortunate truth about most AAA games nowadays.

Performance is the main issue this game seems to have, according to most people. Which they are actually right. I own a 3080Ti and a Ryzen 9 5900x. Both are still pretty solid specs to have to this day, not to mention it's slightly above the recommended. I have the 32GBs of RAM. I have the game installed on an m.2 drive. Yet, despite all that, I cannot run the game above medium settings. Not even with DLSS set to "Ultra Performance." I barely get a solid 60 FPS half the time with the settings on medium-low. Typically the recommended specs allow the game to run fine on high settings, yet that's ... not the case for me. I think most of it is due to the engine: Unreal Engine 5. That engine forces the use of the lumen lighting system, or in some cases, raytracing/RTX. A lot of older GPU's (typically below the RTX 50 series for example) do not have the best support for such a thing, especially since both Lumen and Raytracing are being updated, causing issues for people with older GPU's. They're built for the older versions of ray tracing during the time they were released and being fully supported. Now, being forced to use the newer system, it's not going to end well.

The game itself has it's issues too, not just performance-wise. I have been playing the game a lot with one other person who lives on the opposite side of the planet. Let me tell you, no Borderlands game has ever handled latency well ... at all. I am used to the delay, but it's still often unbearable. Having to aim way ahead from where the enemy will be due to the delay and the time the bullet takes to reach the target. It's a lot worse with torgue weapons or anything else that shoots slow bullets. Movement on foot is fine otherwise, but there's a lot of jank trying to mantle or often times gliding. The game randomly would make me glide around despite pressing space bar once. I'm just stuck floating slowly around, having the game twitch me around violently. Driving is so much worse and practically unbearable, and I'm a little bummed out there's no option to just spawn one car that 4 players can sit in. Playing the older games with the same person, I would always sit in the back of the car and let them drive due to the delay, but now in this game, I'm forced to drive. Turning is really delayed and floaty, and I'll suddenly just bounce back aggressively, sometimes even teleport all the way back to when I first mounted, then the game re-adjusts me back into the right position.

The performance issues, the delay, and now just general bugs that were game-breaking. The most common bug I would get, and I don't know how I constantly did it, but I think it was when I would start a reload and immediately try to swap weapons or use the underbarrel attachment, the gun bugs out. It plays the shooting animations and audio, yet I'm not shooting any bullets at all. Swapping weapons does nothing, yet it says on the bottom right of the screen that I switch weapons, but no animation plays, and I still cannot shoot my gun at all. Dropping my gun and picking it back up would often fix it, but that was a 50/50 chance it'd fix it or not. This was definitely super frustrating when this would happen during boss fights.

Just as often, I would notice suddenly all of my skill points would reset and unequip everything. I'm having to pause the game and try to remember what I had before, or just use it as an opportunity to try a different build. This bug is just both an upside and a downside. Either way, it really shouldn't happen.

Sometimes the icons and rarity with certain items would get mixed up. To the point where an "unequipped" item would actually be equipped. I try to tag it for junk and sell it, but it doesn't work. Then I finally manage to sell it, and suddenly I realized I sold my equipped weapon. I have to buy it back, while this ghost item in my backpack is still there and I cannot sell or get rid of it, as it's apparently my equipped item. I know the game is supposed to warn you about selling an equipped item, but this bug does not make that warning pop up.

The game does have charm to me still. The humor at times made me giggle out loud. But ... there's too much of it. I don't know why they'd include so much modern slang, jokes and memes. Before you worry or panic, no, none of that horrid gen alpha stuff. No forbidden toilet (as far as I've seen at this point). Before the game was coming out, devs stated the game would have way less "toilet humor" yet it's not entirely true. Some of the genuinely funny bits of the game are some things I've heard Rafa say, such as referencing Pokemon or Star Wars (yes this game has soooo many references). His character is actually funny. Harlowe has some silly things to say too. Some of her one liners are great but there's always the weak ones. I don't know much about Amon or Vex since neither me or my friend has played them all that much. Though, if I have to say one thing with Vex, regarding practically every damn siren character in these games, Vex doesn't seem to be as ... self-centered? Amara in 3 was so often talking about how amazing she was, yet from what little bits of Vex I've heard, she's not talking like that as much. Yet, nearly all the characters in the game suffer from having ... too much modern slang to say. That includes the Rippers.

Despite everything though, I still have hope for this game. I still love it. It's really fun to play. The guns in the game can get really crazy, which only makes it much more enjoyable. I really hope this game gets more updates and patches, eventually turning into a fully finished, and enjoyable product with little to no bugs.

There's a lot to be impressed by from a technical and build variety stance but overall the game still manages to be a step back from its progression/endgame from Wonderlands, which is a massive statement to its regression as a series. Alright, I guess I'm doing this.
Me and my fiance have been playing Borderlands together through our entire relationship, going on fifteen years at this point. We've played the entire series all the way through multiple times. We've both played nearly every character to max level, and have always enjoyed playing the game together. When Borderlands 4 came out, people kept saying it wasn't good, but we were skeptical- we heard people ask the question: if it's just another borderlands game, is that enough? Our answer was yes. 

Our answer is still yes. 

But there's no easy way to say this: this doesn't meet that standard. And I'll take the time to go into depth for why.

First, expectations. Most assessments we saw before getting the game were negative. We didn't expect this to rival Borderlands 2. We expected, at best, something more on par with 3. We heard there was a darker tone to this game, and that was actually a welcome idea. Taking the series in a new direction could be a good thing, leaning a little away from the cornball humor might be good for things. So while we weren't expecting anything amazing, there was optimism. 

Then, the tone- the prologue shows you a villain who takes people's free will and does some pretty horrible things. You see, for instance, a man forced to murder all his friends with his bare hands before snapping his own neck, and another man forced to stab himself to death. This villain comes off as very serious, very dangerous. It'd be like if they actually showed you Handsome Jack gouging a man's eyes out with a spoon instead of just mentioning it. But literally the next scene is Claptrap singing some nonsense song about collecting beach trash for change, and we spend time palling around with him as he's his wacky self. What happened to the darker tone? It's a jarring shift. Even the scenery shifts suddenly- the prologue is dark and dreary, fitting with the dark tone, but it suddenly shifts to a vibrant coastal mountain range that almost looks like something out of fortnite. In game, it hardly even looks like Borderlands. The comic book aesthetic is downplayed compared to previous entries.

Next, the gameplay. There are three issues- the guns, the enemies and the player characters. 
Compared to other entries in the series, the guns are HORRIBLY bland and boring. The "boring" manufacturers- that is, the ones that just make "ordinary" weapons- seem to be the best for the chunk of the game i played. Gone are the chargeable Maliwan weapons, the Tediores that sprout legs and chase enemies down when reloaded, the Atlas smart bullets. An assault rifle or a pistol from a given manufacturer will behave pretty much the same as another one- you don't see the variety of effects. Borderlands 3, by comparison, had the guns down. Every manufacturer felt different- a Jakobs felt like a cannon, Tediore felt like something someone 3D printed, Dahl like you were playing CoD... Of all the things to screw up, making the guns feel samey in a Borderlands game is unfathomable, but they did it. 

The enemies lack variety and don't do interesting things. In BL3, Maliwan soldiers moved from cover to cover and fought tactically, COV fought with abandon. It feels like enemies all fight the same in this game- and beyond that, you run into the same kinds over and over. You have Rippers, Timekeeper Minions, and animals- and none of them seem to have unique AI, when they even HAVE functioning AI. The amount of times an enemy will just lock in place and let you shoot them to death is staggering. Beyond that, they're SUCH bullet sponges- a normal enemy of your level should not require you to empty several magazines to take out.

Finally, the characters- this is a weird complaint to have to say, but... you get your toys too fast. In Borderlands, by the end of the game, things get silly- you have a Fire Kreig in BL2 shooting homing exploding fireballs at anyone that hits him, and healing for all the elemental damage he does... but you get this at the end of the game. Similarly, my maxed out Ice Zane in BL3 has permanent action skills because the durations reset every time I freeze something. Things GET silly... but here, my gravitar can delete an entire camp of enemies  with one shot of her action skill by level 10. Without depth, and with guns being so weak in comparison, this gets very boring very fast. 

Finally, the world and characters... they don't fit with this villain at all. You have a villain literally enslaving a planet and forcing people to kill themselves in brutal and horrifying ways, and the first chunk of the game is a sun drenched beachfront paradise brimming with color and characters acting silly. What happened here? Was there some kind of rift in the writing team? The first town is populated by a pack of what I can only call goofy goobers, not a single one of which looks like they're having anything other than the time of their lives. Sure, they SAY they're oppressed, but when you have your alleged resistance leader literally always wearing a huge grin, "anxiety baking" and busting out the star shaped cookie cutters... and the civilians sitting around eating TV dinners in the open while commenting offhandedly that they're not even hungry, they're just eating because they're bored... the town not having a single armed guard, wall or even lookout tower...

Well, I just can't believe that these people are the resistance fighting against the villain you showed me earlier. No.  These people have an overabundance of food, and are apparently so secure that they live in an open town on the road with no means to defend themselves. Were there soft civilians in borderlands 2? Yes, they lived in a walled town full of guards. Were there quirky weirdos hanging around in borderlands 3? Yes, but they were armed and would fight when prompted. 

You might think, some of these reasons to not like it are kinda petty. Well, unfortunately, when your gameplay loop isn't fun, these things really stick out. And this gameplay loop isnt fun. The world is big and empty- like a dead server on an MMO, the enemies are samey, the guns are boring and ineffective, the action skills are cartoonishly imbalanced, the tone is all over the place, and the NPCs don't fit the villain. 

Bottom Line? We both paid over $100 for this game, and it's pretty bad. I don't know if my fiance feels the same, but I feel like I got suckered. In it's current state, HEAVILY not recommended.

I've played Borderlands since its inception. The good, bad, and ugly, not necessarily in the order of game release. This is by far the worst of the bunch. 

Plot and story aside for a moment (because really... who plays Borderlands for its deep story?) Borderlands has always been a looter/shooter. Heck, it invented the concept really with the first rendition. 

Yet in this game, it's gone so far as to become a walking simulator - particularly with the 'fetch' missions - where you must cut off your left hand to carry the item - preventing you from using your grapple, or grenades, or even aim/zoom. 

And the other missions are no better - from one in which the items you need to use in the game are blocked from view by the hazard that kills you in seconds if you don't find it- to arbitrary timers... (Yes, I know those showed up as side missions in other games in the series - including Tiny Tina's). They have drifted from the core of the game to do this... and used what I like to think of as 'Petulant Development'. 

This is where every task, from using the map, to navigating the menus... to using equipment in game and even walking (Because: Invisible walls) to even completing a task, are carried out to such a frustrating degree that it seems deliberate. Every quest destination is as far from any fast-travel location as possible. Every quest has not one or two things to chase down, but 4 and five and six (or more) locations to travel to i n order to complete what should be a simple side quest. Each ensuring you travel as far as possible. 

The devs have no respect for the players time in this game. After all the tedium and slog of going to location after location (Sometimes for no reason than to then go to another location) or every button or device needed for a quest failing to work unless part X is obtained (Which is always clear across the map) first... This is fine if there's a reward afterwards... 

But, there's a reason they added a keyboard mapping for picking up junk - everything that drops, is.  (I have hundreds of hours of play time and yet maybe 20 legendary items to show for it) makes every chest, every boss, every trash mob, simply not worth the time spent killing them, let alone, wasting time farming them on repeat. 

There's a reason fewer than 40% of players have even reached max level yet... and it's not merely 'Performance issues' that are the root cause. It's because no one has the time to spend doing what is arguably fun (The game still and always has great gun play) only to find all your time yielded notta for a reward. When combined with all the tedium the game offers up on the way to what should be a decent reward only to find it's 2 sticks and a piece of pocket lint instead, it adds to the frustration. Not because the gunplay itself is 'hard'... but because the game is over-the-top needlessly tedious. 

Your mileage may vary - and I'm not suggesting it's not a step in the right direction for the franchise in some respects (Summon vehicles anywhere/gliding/teleport to friends)- but this is the first time I've ever felt like not playing a game due to the petulant way in which the developers curtail the fun by removing the rewards, and gleefully think that's a good thing. When It actually leaves a blemish on the series as a whole.

Borderlands 4 comes with [i]severe[/i] bugs and crashes. As of writing you are [u]guaranteed[/u] to encounter issues during your playthrough. I played the game together with several friends, all of whom are tech savvy hardcore gamers. All of us had played the previous titles as well and each of us had constant and repeating problems with Borderlands 4. This game should not have been released in this state.

I don't like to speculate on whether or not any issues will be addressed by the developer (if at all) but previous Borderlands titles (despite all their massive problems around launch) were not in nearly in as sorry a state on release. Save yourself the disappointment and just wait this one out.


Beyond that, if you come from the previous titles in the series, you might want to know this:

- No LAN support anymore.
Borderlands 4 is a typical "always online" game experience. You will get disconnected every once in a while, even if you are sitting in the same room and the rest of the internet keeps on working on your machines. Could be their servers, could be the ISP but either way it's a free dose of frustration coming you way regularly. We all know there's no need to be always-online for a co-op game you want to play with friends. It creates a miserable and frustrating experience - welcome to modern gaming.

- Optimization is atrocious.
People are not making this up. You can not get stable frametimes on a 4090, nor on a 5090, nor on a 5070 on lowest settings. No matter if you use the latest drivers or run DDU to try stable drivers from over a year ago, your frametimes will be all over the place. We are fairly tech savvy but each of us suffered without caving in and enabling DLSS or frame gen (which causes us to suffer in return - I'll spare you my musings here).

- Crashes at random intervals.
The game will crash on every system at some point if you play longer sessions. We have a sample size of 4 hardcore no-lifer gamers who can play 10 hours every day without a single hiccup or crash, yet Borderlands 4 will have issues regularly for every single one of us. It's not tied to specific in-game content, it's not tied to hardware, it's just broken code that needs fixing. If you can't handle missing out on loot or progress from having a crash happen at the worst of timings, then please spare yourself the frustration.

- Lots of bugs.
The game has several bugs and glitches. What gets annoying in multiplayer specifically: Talents are resetting in the talent screen randomly on non-host machines. Netcode causes jitter in moving surfaces or vehicles players are supposed to walk on. The good old "Items can fall through the floor" is also still a thing (on very flat and visually safe terrain mind you). You will find talents and procs not firing, despite you meeting all conditions.

- Bad UI on PC
Borderlands always had a "console-friendly" UI but this time around there's a lot of "quick tap to do one action, hold button to do a completely different action" baked into inventory management. To compare items in your inventory you need to press R once. If you want to drop the item you need to hold R for a while. You can imagine how fun this gets if you do it for 50 items you want to share with friends. Some UI elements are not showing up correctly for some players (despite them being on the right step of a mission). The minimap is frustrating to handle (and mandatory for traveling). They're all downgrades over the previous games.

- Realtime rendered cutscenes are locked to 30fps (for no reason whatsoever).
You can look forward to watching stuttery scenes regularly during the campaign. If you are locked into fast paced combat, your screen fades for the a fraction of a second and you get draged into 30fps of wonky cutscenes you are bound to notice what's going on. Good luck trying to ignore how jarring that is.

In some ways it's a good game, but in others they've managed to create a bad Borderlands game.

In my opinion, the best game in the series was Borderlands 2. While Borderlands 3 significantly improved the gameplay and graphics, it made the story and characters quite boring. Still, its similarities to Borderlands 2 made it somehow bearable.
Borderlands 4, however, took this a step further. They improved the gameplay even more, but managed to make the story and characters even more boring. Unfortunately, I can't say the same for the graphics and the art style.

While the Unreal Engine technically offers much more advanced features, I don't see them in the game. There's no special RTX lighting effects, no realistic water effects, or stunning scenery. Despite all this, the game loads much slower, leaving you constantly waiting for shaders to load. The cartoony art style we were accustomed to in Borderlands 1 and 2 is gone, and the tone-down makes it feel like you're playing just another looter shooter.

Choosing an Elden Ring-esque "open world" map is a huge mistake. The problem isn't the expansiveness of the map itself, but its presentation. You walk around as if you're going to discover hidden places (Borderlands 2, for example, would have hidden areas or trophies from places you'd never even consider), but the place you reach turns out to be just a random monster kill zone. This significantly diminishes the exploration experience.

While the map design initially evokes the Elden Ring vibe, it unfortunately lacks the lore-informing details or small references that game offers. This makes the open-world map feel even more empty. Yes, the game offers the opportunity to collect bubble heads. But they're so small, you might miss them even if you look carefully. This detracts from the sense of discovery you get from the game, not enhances it.

The movement features they attempted in Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel (long jumping and flying) are much more successfully implemented here. I'll give the developers credit for that. Things like flying around the map, jumping, hopping, and double-jumping are much more fun than driving. However, the lack of hidden areas I mentioned and the problems with the open-world map exploration significantly diminish the usefulness of these jumping mechanics.

The storytelling, which was so annoying to me in Borderlands 3, centered on the "preventable deaths of supporting characters," feels even more intense here. This diminishes the excitement you should get from the main story.

Borderlands 3's endgame raid maps offered a very enjoyable experience. Here, they've eliminated that and filled it solely with boss challenges. This further diminishes the enjoyment of the game. By the end of the game, builds that force you into quick fights among dozens of enemies are meaningless; the only important weapons and builds that allow you to one-shot bosses are the ones that matter.

They've included a lot of customization in the game, but it doesn't really make sense when you're playing. You find yourself constantly killing the same creatures in the same places. And all these customization options don't offer any additional fun or immersion.

I think instead of releasing this game, they would have been better off creating an MMORPG set in Borderlands 1-2-3. Instead of a "vault hunter," playing a soldier from a major Corporation, trying to rise to the top (like Rhys or Jack), while simultaneously fighting through the story of another game with each expansion, would have been a much more enjoyable experience. This open-world infrastructure they've created would have had more meaning.
